content:
Section 212(a)(3)(B)(i) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include aliens identified in the terrorist screening database, with an exception for those lawfully admitted for permanent residence. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to prevent the deportation of aliens identified in the terrorist screening database, with exceptions for those lawfully admitted for permanent residence. Additionally, waivers of inadmissibility grounds are provided for such aliens. Section 212(d)(3) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow for individual case-by-case waivers for aliens deemed to be in the national security interests of the United States to be granted nonimmigrant visas and admitted. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow for waivers for aliens to be granted nonimmigrant visas and admitted into the United States temporarily under certain conditions. The Secretary of Homeland Security may grant a waiver with the unanimous concurrence of key officials. SEC. 4. UNAVAILABILITY OF CERTAIN IMMIGRATION BENEFITS TO ALIENS IDENTIFIED IN TERRORIST SCREENING DATABASE. (a) Amendment to asylum provision under the Immigration and Nationality Act to include a new category.
(b) Amendment to withholding of removal provision to include specific inadmissibility and deportability criteria.
(c) Amendment to cancellation of removal provision for certain permanent residents regarding inadmissibility. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act regarding inadmissibility and deportability criteria for certain nonpermanent residents. It also addresses voluntary departure provisions. The Nationality Act is amended to restrict aliens from voluntarily departing if they were previously found inadmissible or are inadmissible or deportable under specific sections. Additionally, adjustments to the Immigration and Nationality Act are made regarding inadmissibility and deportability criteria for certain nonpermanent residents. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to update criteria for inadmissibility and deportability, including restrictions on aliens voluntarily departing if they fall under specific sections. The changes also affect the Registry section and the Convention Against Torture. The Secretary of Homeland Security must revise regulations implementing the Convention Against Torture within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The revisions will exclude certain aliens from protection and ensure they are ineligible for withholding or deferral of removal under immigration laws. The revised regulations must allow for reopening and readjudication of determinations made before the effective date, applying to acts and conditions of ineligibility for protection, regardless of when they occurred. SEC. 5. EXPEDITED REMOVAL OF ALIENS INADMISSIBLE OR DEPORTABLE ON SECURITY AND RELATED GROUNDS. Section 238 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow for the removal of aliens who are not permanent residents and are inadmissible or deportable on security or related grounds. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the authority to determine the inadmissibility or deportability of such aliens. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for the removal of aliens who are inadmissible or deportable on security grounds. The Secretary of Homeland Security can determine the inadmissibility or deportability of such aliens. Aliens who are inadmissible or deportable on security grounds can be removed under section 237(a)(4)(B) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. An order of removal can be issued following specific procedures outlined in the Act. This applies to aliens who have not been granted a waiver under section 212(d)(3)(C) and were not lawfully admitted for permanent residence or had conditional permanent resident status at the time proceedings commenced. Proceedings under this subsection for aliens inadmissible or deportable on security grounds are expedited, following regulations set by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The alien must be given notice of charges, have the right to representation, inspect evidence, and rebut charges. The process for judicial review of removal orders includes verifying the identity of the individual, maintaining a record for review, and ensuring the final order is not adjudicated by the same person who issued the charges. The Secretary of Homeland Security must wait 14 days before executing the order to allow the alien to apply for judicial review. Aliens adjudicated inadmissible or deportable are ineligible for discretionary relief from removal. Aliens adjudicated inadmissible or deportable are ineligible for discretionary relief from removal. The Act and its amendments will be effective upon enactment and will apply to all individuals in the terrorist screening database from that date onwards.
